Front: Define: aseptic (uh-sep-tik)
Back: adj. free of pathogens or germs adj. with little or no emotion Doctors are always careful to use aseptic surgical equipment to prevent infection. Prefix: a- (from Greek, meaning “not” or “without”); Root: sept (from Greek sēptikos, meaning “putrefying”)

Front: Define: prolix (proh-liks)
Back: adj. wordy or prolonged; tedious in length The prolix manuscript took days to read. Prefix: pro- (from Latin, meaning “forward”); Root: lix (from Latin liquere, meaning “to flow”)

Front: Define: foolhardy (fool-hahr-dee)
Back: adj. reckless, unwisely bold; thoughtlessly rash It was a foolhardy attempt to climb the Sears Tower that went very wrong. Root: fool (from Old French fol, meaning “foolish”); Suffix: -hardy (from Old French hardi, meaning “bold”)

Front: Define: picaresque (pik-uh-resk)
Back: adj. involving clever rogues in episodes of comedy or adventure Huck Finn is a picaresque hero. Root: picaro (from Spanish, meaning “rogue” or “rascal”); Suffix: -esque (from French, meaning “in the style of”)

Front: Define: raucous (raw-kuhs)
Back: adj. rough sounding, harsh adj. boisterous, rowdy, disorderly The raucous laughter went on long into the night. Root: rauc (from Latin raucus, meaning “hoarse”)

Front: Define: providential (prov-ih-den-shuhl)
Back: adj. to occur as if from divine intervention or great time His providential recovery, when it seemed that he would surely succumb, brought hope to many. Root: provident (from Latin providentia, meaning “foresight”); Suffix: -ial (forming adjectives)

Front: Define: antipodal (an-tip-uh-dl)
Back: adj. diametrically opposed to, polar opposite adj. on the opposite side of the earth The couple had totally antipodal personalities, but they enjoyed each other's company. Prefix: anti- (from Greek, meaning “opposite”); Root: pod (from Greek pous, meaning “foot”); Suffix: -al (forming adjectives)

Front: Define: pillory (pill-uh-ree)
Back: v. to punish; to hold up for public scorning n. a wooden framework with holes for head and hands, in which criminal offenders are held Dan was pilloried in class for his inability to spell “potato”. Root: pillar (from Old French pilori, meaning “pillar”)

Front: Define: infelicitous (in-fuh-liss-ih-tuss)
Back: adj. unfortunate, awkward, inappropriate In Thailand, it is considered infelicitous to touch someone's head. Prefix: in- (from Latin, meaning “not”); Root: felicit (from Latin felicitas, meaning “happiness”); Suffix: -ous (forming adjectives)

Front: Define: dilatory (dil-uh-tawr-ee)
Back: adj. tending to delay, put off, or procrastinate adj. intended to slow progress Courtney employed dilatory tactics in the debate in order to collect her thoughts, but the judges noticed and she was docked a point. Root: dilat (from Latin dilatus, meaning “deferred”); Suffix: -ory (forming adjectives)

Front: Define: overweening (oh-ver-wee-ning)
Back: adj. presumptuously arrogant or conceited; overconfident, overbearing Ian made the overweening assumption that people would rush to help him. Prefix: over- (meaning “excessive”); Root: ween (from Old English wenan, meaning “to think”); Suffix: -ing (forming adjectives)

Front: Define: neologism (nee-awl-uh-djiz-uhm)
Back: n. the creation of new words, expressions, or usages for words “Technophile” is a neologism, just as “UFO” once was. Prefix: neo- (from Greek, meaning “new”); Root: log (from Greek logos, meaning “word”); Suffix: -ism (forming nouns indicating a practice or system)

Front: Define: lassitude (lass-ih-tood)
Back: n. a state of listless exhaustion, weakness, or weariness of the mind or body The extreme heat led to a general lassitude that settled on the village from May to October. Root: lass (from Latin lassus, meaning “weary”); Suffix: -itude (forming nouns indicating a state or condition)

Front: Define: locution (loh-kyoo-shuhn)
Back: n. a particular word, phrase, or style used by a person or group n. style of speaking, phraseology The newcomers were fascinated by the Aussie's locution. Root: locut (from Latin loqui, meaning “to speak”); Suffix: -ion (forming nouns indicating an action or condition)

Front: Define: jocose (joh-kohss)
Back: adj. characterized by a joking or humorous manner The jocose innkeeper could always be counted on for a bit of levity. Root: joc (from Latin jocus, meaning “joke”); Suffix: -ose (forming adjectives indicating fullness or abundance)

Front: Define: rend (rend)
Back: v. to forcibly take v. to tear apart The three-year-old decided she wants to play with the teddy bear, so she rended it from her infant sister's hands. Root: rend (from Old English rendan, meaning “to tear”)

Front: Define: stanch (stawnch)
Back: v. to cease the flow of a liquid (esp. blood) The doctor's attempt to stanch the flow of blood eventually succeeded, and the patient's blood pressure stabilized. Root: stanch (from Latin stare, meaning “to stand”)

Front: Define: solder (sod-er)
Back: v. to weld, fuse, or join (esp. metals) Harry soldered the bits of scrap metal together to make a pet door. Root: solder (from Latin solidare, meaning “to make solid”)

Front: Define: demure (duh-myoor)
Back: adj. modest, shy Lindsay was demure and had a tough time opening up to new people. Prefix: de- (from Latin, meaning “down” or “away”); Root: mure (from Old French murer, meaning “to wall”)

Front: Define: insensible (in-sen-suh-buhl)
Back: adj. unconscious, unresponsive The boxer lay insensible on the floor of the ring. Prefix: in- (from Latin, meaning “not”); Root: sens (from Latin sentire, meaning “to feel”); Suffix: -ible (forming adjectives indicating capability)

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. free of pathogens or germs adj. with little or no emotion Hint: starts with “a”
Back: aseptic synonyms: barren, clean; withdrawn, introverted, sterile, unemotional The hospital room was kept aseptic to prevent infections. His aseptic demeanor made it hard to read his feelings.

Front: Fill in the blank: The professor's ________ lecture caused several students to lose focus. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “tediously wordy”.
Back: prolix prolix (proh-liks) adj. wordy or prolonged; tedious in length

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. reckless, unwisely bold; thoughtlessly rash Hint: starts with “f”
Back: foolhardy synonyms: daredevil, venturous, risky, audacious, imprudent His foolhardy decision to drive through the storm led to disaster.

Front: Fill in the blank: The novel's ________ hero was always getting into mischief. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “relating to adventures of a roguish hero”.
Back: picaresque picaresque (pik-uh-resk) adj. involving clever rogues in episodes of comedy or adventure

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. rough sounding, harsh adj. boisterous, rowdy, disorderly Hint: starts with “r”
Back: raucous synonyms: noisy, chaotic, loud, clamorous, disorderly The raucous laughter filled the noisy bar. The raucous crowd disrupted the concert.

Front: Fill in the blank: Their ________ meeting led to a lifelong friendship. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “fortunate or timely”.
Back: providential providential (prov-ih-den-shuhl) adj. to occur as if from divine intervention

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. diametrically opposed to, polar opposite adj. on the opposite side of the earth Hint: starts with “a”
Back: antipodal synonyms: opposed, contrary, counter, opposite, divergent Their views on politics were antipodal. Australia and Argentina are antipodal regions.

Front: Fill in the blank: He was ________ in the press for his controversial remarks. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “publicly ridiculed or punished”.
Back: pilloried pillory (pill-uh-ree) v. to punish; to hold up for public scorning n. a wooden framework with holes for head and hands, in which criminal offenders are held

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. unfortunate, awkward, inappropriate Hint: starts with “i”
Back: infelicitous synonyms: improper, ill-suited, inopportune, unsuitable His infelicitous comment ruined the otherwise pleasant dinner.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her ________ approach to her work caused deadlines to be missed. Hint: Starts with “d” and means “slow to act”.
Back: dilatory dilatory (dil-uh-tawr-ee) adj. tending to delay, put off, or procrastinate adj. intended to slow progress

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. presumptuously arrogant or conceited, overconfident, overbearing Hint: starts with “o”
Back: overweening synonyms: brash, conceited, pompous, hubristic, egotistical His overweening arrogance made him unpopular among his colleagues.

Front: Fill in the blank: The tech industry is full of ________ that are hard to keep up with. Hint: Starts with “n” and means “a newly coined word or phrase”.
Back: neologism neologism (nee-awl-uh-djiz-uhm) n. the creation of new words, expressions, or usages for words

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a state of listless exhaustion, weakness, or weariness of the mind or body Hint: starts with “l”
Back: lassitude synonyms: lethargy, weariness, fatigue, listlessness, apathy After the long hike, she was overcome with lassitude.

Front: Fill in the blank: His ________ was filled with regional slang that made him hard to understand. Hint: Starts with “l” and means “a style of speech or expression”.
Back: locution locution (loh-kyoo-shuhn) n. a particular word, phrase, or style used by a person or group n. style of speaking, phraseology

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. characterized by a joking or humorous manner Hint: starts with “j”
Back: jocose synonyms: facetious, humorous, funny, playful, lighthearted His jocose personality made him the life of the party.

Front: Fill in the blank: He tried to ________ the book from her hands. Hint: Starts with “r” and means “to tear apart violently”.
Back: rend rend (rend) v. to forcibly take v. to tear apart

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to cease the flow of a liquid (esp. blood) Hint: starts with “s”
Back: stanch synonyms: halt, stop, quench, check The nurse quickly stanched the bleeding.

Front: Fill in the blank: He carefully ________ the broken circuit board back together. Hint: Starts with “s” and means “joined metal parts together”.
Back: soldered solder (sod-er) v. to weld, fuse, or join (esp. metals)

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. modest, shy Hint: starts with “d”
Back: demure synonyms: reserved, bashful, coy, retiring, unassuming She gave a demure smile when complimented.

Front: Fill in the blank: He was ________ after being hit on the head. Hint: Starts with “i” and means “unconscious or unaware”.
Back: insensible insensible (in-sen-suh-buhl) adj. unconscious, unresponsive

Front: Define: rail (reyl)
Back: v. to complain bitterly The citizens railed against the injustice of the federal land grab in tersely-worded editorials and letters to the editor. Root: regula (from Latin, meaning “a straight stick”)

Front: Define: noisome (noy-suhm)
Back: adj. unpleasant (smell) or harmful The noisome odor of the garbage nauseated Audrey. Suffix: -some (from Old English, meaning “tending to” or “causing”)

Front: Define: mellifluous (muh-lif-loo-uhs)
Back: adj. sweetly flowing (esp. of words or sounds) Lucy's mellifluous voice was noted by her interviewer. Prefix: melli- (from Latin mel, meaning “honey”); Root: fluere (from Latin, meaning “to flow”)

Front: Define: inveterate (in-vet-er-it)
Back: adj. established, habitual, deep-rooted It was Tony's inveterate preference to drink orange juice every morning. Prefix: in- (from Latin, meaning “in” or “into”); Root: vetus (from Latin, meaning “old”)

Front: Define: coterie (koh-tuh-ree)
Back: n. a small or exclusive group of people with common interests The coterie of musicians began to meet on Tuesday nights and eventually established a weekly concert series. Root: cote (from Old French, meaning “cottage” or “hut”)

Front: Define: impugn (im-pyoon)
Back: v. to challenge or attack one's beliefs or motives as false The candidate went too far when he began to impugn the character of his opponent's husband. Prefix: im- (from Latin, meaning “against”); Root: pugnare (from Latin, meaning “to fight”)

Front: Define: voluble (vol-yuh-buhl)
Back: adj. able to speak easily and in quantity, glib, talkative The voluble speaker talked late into the night. Root: volvere (from Latin, meaning “to turn” or “to roll”)

Front: Define: misogynist (mih-sodj-uh-nist)
Back: n. one who hates women The song contained several lyrics that were so offensive to women that the singer was immediately labeled a misogynist. Prefix: miso- (from Greek, meaning “hatred”); Root: gyn (from Greek gynē, meaning “woman”)

Front: Define: pedagogy (ped-uh-goh-djee)
Back: n. the art or profession of training, teaching, or instructing Training in pedagogy can't prepare you for manic third graders. Root: ped (from Greek pais, meaning “child”); Suffix: -agogy (from Greek agogos, meaning “leader”)

Front: Define: ambient (am-bee-uhnt)
Back: adj. relating to the immediate surroundings; surrounding environment The low ambient lighting made for a romantic dinner setting. Prefix: ambi- (from Latin, meaning “around”); Root: ire (from Latin, meaning “to go”)

Front: Define: inquest (in-kwest)
Back: n. a judicial inquiry of some matter held before a jury n. an investigation, inquiry The police opened an inquest into the cause of death. Prefix: in- (from Latin, meaning “in” or “into”); Root: quaerere (from Latin, meaning “to seek”)

Front: Define: preen (preen)
Back: v. to primp, to dress up v. to clean fur or feathers of an animal The bird preened its feathers with its beak for a few moments before taking flight.

Front: Define: parry (pear-ee)
Back: v. to block, evade, or ward off The politician parried the reporter's questions with a few of her own. Root: parare (from Latin, meaning “to prepare” or “to ward off”)

Front: Define: guy (gahy)
Back: n. rope or cord attached to something as a brace I was nervous that the guy for the pulley would snap.

Front: Define: sallow (sal-oh)
Back: adj. of a sickly yellowish hue or complexion There was a large number of sallow-looking patients in the doctor's office.

Front: Define: plangent (plan-djuhnt)
Back: adj. pounding, thundering, resounding The plangent honking of geese flying overhead jolted me awake. Root: plangere (from Latin, meaning “to strike” or “to lament”)

Front: Define: peripatetic (per-uh-puh-tet-ik)
Back: adj. itinerant, nomadic A peripatetic existence can take its toll on your relationships with the ones you love. Prefix: peri- (from Greek, meaning “around”); Root: patein (from Greek, meaning “to walk”)

Front: Define: rue (roo)
Back: v. to regret; to feel or experience remorse I rued the day I ever let her go.

Front: Define: macerate (mass-uh-reyt)
Back: v. to soften by steeping in a liquid, or decompose v. to emaciate; to starve Now, we will macerate the rest of the melon in hot water so we can use it to flavor the cream. Root: macerare (from Latin, meaning “to soften” or “to steep”)

Front: Define: callow (kal-oh)
Back: adj. lacking maturity or experience A callow young man was tormenting the elderly in the park.

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to complain bitterly Hint: starts with “r”
Back: rail synonyms: berate, abuse, complain, rant, criticize She railed against the unfair treatment she received.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ fumes made it difficult to breathe. Hint: Starts with “n” and means “offensive or harmful”.
Back: noisome noisome (noy-suhm) adj. offensive or harmful

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. sweetly flowing (esp. of words or sounds) Hint: starts with “m”
Back: mellifluous synonyms: euphonic, harmonic, mellow, pleasing, smooth, soothing Her mellifluous voice captivated the audience.

Front: Fill in the blank: He was an ________ smoker despite numerous attempts to quit. Hint: Starts with “i” and means “firmly established habit”.
Back: inveterate inveterate (in-vet-er-it) adj. established, habitual, deep-rooted

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a small or exclusive group of people with common interests Hint: starts with “c”
Back: coterie synonyms: clique, crowd, collective, group, association She belonged to an elite coterie of art collectors.

Front: Fill in the blank: He ________ her integrity during the heated debate. Hint: Starts with “i” and means “challenged as false”.
Back: impugned impugn (im-pyoon) v. to challenge or attack ones beliefs or motives as false

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. able to speak easily and in quantity, glib, talkative Hint: starts with “v”
Back: voluble synonyms: articulate, chatty, conversational, talkative, garrulous The voluble speaker entertained the crowd for hours.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ was known for his discriminatory views. Hint: Starts with “m” and means “one who dislikes women”.
Back: misogynist misogynist (mih-sodj-uh-nist) n. one who hates women

Front: Name the vocab term: n. the art or profession of training, teaching, or instructing Hint: starts with “p”
Back: pedagogy synonyms: education, apprenticeship, discipline, instruction, teaching She excelled in pedagogy, making complex subjects accessible to students.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ noise of the city made it hard to concentrate. Hint: Starts with “a” and means “surrounding on all sides”.
Back: ambient ambient (am-bee-uhnt) adj. relating to the immediate surroundings; surrounding environment

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a judicial inquiry of some matter held before a jury. n. an investigation, inquiry Hint: starts with “i”
Back: inquest synonyms: a judicial inquiry, an official review before a panel, investigation, examination The court held an inquest into the cause of the accident.

Front: Fill in the blank: The bird ________ its feathers in the sunlight. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “groomed or dressed with care”.
Back: preened preen (preen) v. to primp, to dress up v. to clean fur or feathers of an animal

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to block, evade, or ward off Hint: starts with “p”
Back: parry synonyms: block, dodge, circumvent, deflect, counter He skillfully parried his opponent's attack.

Front: Fill in the blank: The tent was secured with a ________ to withstand the wind. Hint: Starts with “g” and means “a rope or cable for steadying something”.
Back: guy guy (gahy) n. rope or cord attached to something as a brace

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. of a sickly yellowish hue or complexion Hint: starts with “s”
Back: sallow synonyms: pale, unhealthy-looking, jaundiced, sickly, wan Her sallow complexion was a sign of her illness.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ roar of the waves echoed through the cliffs. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “having a mournful sound”.
Back: plangent plangent (plan-djuhnt) adj. pounding, thundering, resounding

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. itinerant, nomadic Hint: starts with “p”
Back: peripatetic synonyms: migrant, vagrant, wandering, traveling, roving His peripatetic lifestyle took him all over the world.

Front: Fill in the blank: He ________ the day he made that fateful decision. Hint: Starts with “r” and means “regretted”.
Back: rued rue (roo) v. to regret; to feel or experience remorse

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to soften by steeping in a liquid, or decompose v. to emaciate; to starve Hint: starts with “m”
Back: macerate synonyms: soak, dissolve, break down, soften The fruit was left to macerate in the wine overnight. The harsh conditions caused the prisoners to macerate.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ youth made many naive mistakes. Hint: Starts with “c” and means “inexperienced or immature”.
Back: callow callow (kal-oh) adj. lacking maturity or experience

Front: Define: wistful (wist-fuhl)
Back: adj. yearning, longing, or melancholy The child stared wistfully out the window for days, waiting for her dog to return. Suffix: -ful (meaning 'full of')

Front: Define: corroborate (kuh-rob-uh-rehyt)
Back: v. to confirm or validate The mailman corroborated the alleged thief's story, confirming that he had merely been passing by when the robbery occurred. Prefix: cor- (from Latin com-, meaning 'together'); Root: robor (from Latin roborare, meaning 'to strengthen')

Front: Define: couch (couch)
Back: v. to express in indirect terms; to frame in a certain way Her criticism was couched in flattering terms so that her coworker wouldn't take offense. Root: couch (from Old French coucher, meaning 'to lay down')

Front: Define: innervate (ih-nur-veyt)
Back: v. to give nervous energy to; to supply with nerves The team was innervated by the coach's pep talk and approached the second half with renewed energy. Prefix: in- (meaning 'into'); Root: nerve (relating to nerves or the nervous system)

Front: Define: impecunious (im-puh-kyoo-nee-us)
Back: adj. poor; without any money A graduate student generally leads an impecunious existence. Prefix: im- (meaning 'not'); Root: pecun (from Latin pecunia, meaning 'money')

Front: Define: grovel (gruhv-uhl)
Back: v. to behave in a servile manner to receive forgiveness or a favor v. to kneel with one's head down The servants groveled at the king's throne. Root: grovel (from Middle English grovelen, meaning 'to lie face downward')

Front: Define: epicurean (ep-ih-kyoo-ree-uhn)
Back: adj. characterized by luxury (esp. in terms of food and drink) or by a propensity for indulging in luxury The cruise was marketed as an epicurean adventure through the cuisines of four Caribbean nations. Root: Epicure (from the Greek philosopher Epicurus, associated with pleasure and luxury)

Front: Define: hirsute (hur-soot)
Back: adj. hairy, shaggy A hirsute sheepdog won the Dog Showing Contest. Root: hirsut (from Latin hirsutus, meaning 'hairy')

Front: Define: countenance (koun-tuh-nunce)
Back: n. appearance of a person's face v. to permit, to allow Many people thought she was friendly because of her kindly countenance. Root: counten (from Latin continentia, meaning 'bearing' or 'demeanor')

Front: Define: scurvy (skur-vee)
Back: adj. not admirable, despicable The scurvy pirate secured his escape by throwing gun powder into the eyes of his pursuers. Root: scurv (from Old English scurf, meaning 'scaly skin')

Front: Define: covert (koe-vert)
Back: adj. hidden; secret The government's covert operations were laid bare by the shocking article. Root: cover (from Old French covrir, meaning 'to cover')

Front: Define: craven (kray-vun)
Back: adj. cowardly The craven man ran away at the first sign of danger. Root: crav (from Old French cravent, meaning 'defeated')

Front: Define: eugenics (yoo-djen-iks)
Back: n. the study of heredity improvements by genetic control Nazi Germany is known to have carried out many eugenics experiments that provoked outrage once they came to light. Prefix: eu- (meaning 'good' or 'well'); Root: gen (from Greek genos, meaning 'race' or 'kind')

Front: Define: credence (creed-enss)
Back: n. belief that something is true n. plausibility She gave credence to the rumors when she failed to deny them. Root: cred (from Latin credere, meaning 'to believe')

Front: Define: execrate (ek-si-kreyt)
Back: v. to declare to be hateful or abhorrent; denounce v. to loathe v. to curse The rival teams appeared on the news to execrate one another. Prefix: ex- (meaning 'out'); Root: secr (from Latin sacer, meaning 'sacred')

Front: Define: sempiternal (sem-pih-tur-nl)
Back: adj. eternal, infinite Nothing in life is sempiternal, alas. Prefix: sem- (from Latin semper, meaning 'always'); Root: etern (meaning 'eternal')

Front: Define: credulous (kredj-uh-luss)
Back: adj. easily convinced that something is true His lies were so ridiculous that only the most credulous child would have believed them. Root: cred (from Latin credere, meaning 'to believe'); Suffix: -ous (meaning 'full of')

Front: Define: plumb (pluhm)
Back: v. to measure the depth v. to examine critically I think she is the only architect working today who has the courage to truly plumb the possibilities of recycled construction materials. Root: plumb (from Latin plumbum, meaning 'lead')

Front: Define: culpable (kull-puh-bull)
Back: adj. deserving of blame or punishment He confessed that he was culpable for the crime and faced the consequences. Root: culp (from Latin culpa, meaning 'fault' or 'blame'); Suffix: -able (meaning 'capable of')

Front: Define: debase (dih-base)
Back: v. to corrupt or lower the value of Many argue that modern society has been debased by materialism. Prefix: de- (meaning 'down' or 'away'); Root: base (meaning 'low' or 'bottom')

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. yearning, longing, or melancholy Hint: starts with “w”
Back: wistful synonyms: forlorn, reflective, pensive, melancholic She gave a wistful glance at the old photographs, remembering better times.

Front: Fill in the blank: The witness's testimony ________ the alibi of the defendant. Hint: Starts with “c” and means “confirmed or supported”.
Back: corroborated corroborate (kuh-rob-uh-rehyt) v. to confirm or validate

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to express in indirect terms; to frame in a certain way Hint: starts with “c”
Back: couch synonyms: formulate, phrase, surround, present, articulate She couched her criticism in more diplomatic language to avoid offense.

Front: Fill in the blank: The motivational speech ________ the team before the big game. Hint: Starts with “i” and means “supplied with nerves”.
Back: innervated innervate (ih-nur-veyt) v. to give nervous energy to; to supply with nerves

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. poor; without any money Hint: starts with “i”
Back: impecunious synonyms: destitute, impoverished, broke, needy He was impecunious after years of struggling to find steady work.

Front: Fill in the blank: They ________ to win favor with the influential leader. Hint: Starts with “g” and means “acted in a servile way”.
Back: groveled grovel (gruhv-uhl) v. to behave in a servile manner v. to indulge in unworthy pursuits

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. characterized by luxury (esp. in terms of food and drink) or by a propensity for indulging in luxury Hint: starts with “e”
Back: epicurean synonyms: gluttonous, libertine, luxurious, indulgent The epicurean feast featured the finest wines and gourmet dishes.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ dog left fur all over the furniture. Hint: Starts with “h” and means “hairy”.
Back: hirsute hirsute (hur-soot) adj. hairy, shaggy

Front: Name the vocab term: n. appearance of a person's face v. to permit, to allow Hint: starts with “c”
Back: countenance synonyms: aspect, demeanor, expression; face, approval His serious countenance made him look older than his years. The manager countenanced the team's request for a day off.

Front: Fill in the blank: His ________ behavior left him with few friends. Hint: Starts with “s” and means “despicable or contemptible”.
Back: scurvy scurvy (skur-vee) adj. not admirable, despicable

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. hidden; secret n. a covered place for hiding Hint: starts with “c”
Back: covert synonyms: cloaked, secret, sly, concealed, hidden The agent's covert operation was unknown to most of his colleagues. The fox darted into the covert to avoid the hunters.

Front: Fill in the blank: His ________ refusal to stand up for his beliefs cost him his reputation. Hint: Starts with “c” and means “cowardly”.
Back: craven craven (kray-vun) adj. cowardly

Front: Name the vocab term: n. the study of heredity improvements by genetic control Hint: starts with “e”
Back: eugenics synonyms: genetic enhancement, genetic manipulation, biogenetics The controversial theory of eugenics has raised ethical concerns over the years.

Front: Fill in the blank: The scientist's findings lent ________ to the new theory. Hint: Starts with “c” and means “belief or acceptance as true”.
Back: credence credence (creed-enss) n. belief that something is true n. plausibility

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to declare to be hateful or abhorrent; denounce v. to loathe v. to curse Hint: starts with “e”
Back: execrate synonyms: accurse, condemn; hate, detest, revile The dictator was execrated by the people for his brutal regime. She execrated the idea of injustice.

Front: Fill in the blank: The stars in the sky seem ________, twinkling throughout the ages. Hint: Starts with “s” and means “everlasting”.
Back: sempiternal sempiternal (sem-pih-tur-nl) adj. eternal, infinite

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. easily convinced that something is true Hint: starts with “c”
Back: credulous synonyms: gullible, too trusting, naive, unsuspecting The credulous child believed every story his older brother told him.

Front: Fill in the blank: They used a rope to ________ the depths of the ocean. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “to measure depth or examine closely”.
Back: plumb plumb (pluhm) v. to measure the depth v. to examine critically

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. deserving of blame or punishment Hint: starts with “c”
Back: culpable synonyms: guilty, liable, responsible, accountable He was found culpable for the accident and faced legal consequences.

Front: Fill in the blank: The scandal ________ the reputation of the company. Hint: Starts with “d” and means “lowered in quality or value”.
Back: debased debase (dih-base) v. to corrupt or lower the value of

Front: Define: decadent (deck-ih-dunt)
Back: adj. in a state of decline adj. self-indulgent Louis XIV was known for his decadent displays of wealth and power. Prefix: de- (from Latin, meaning “down” or “away”), Root: cad (from Latin cadere, meaning “to fall”)

Front: Define: decorous (dek-core-us)
Back: adj. conforming to what is acceptable to society adj. marked by propriety and etiquette One must always behave in a decorous manner at formal events. Root: decor (from Latin decorus, meaning “proper” or “becoming”)

Front: Define: decry (dih-cry)
Back: v. to strongly disapprove of The preacher decried society's indifference towards the poor. Prefix: de- (from Latin, meaning “down” or “away”), Root: cry (from Old French crier, meaning “to cry out”)

Front: Define: artless (art-liss)
Back: adj. simple and natural adj. unable to mask true feelings adj. without artistic merit; crudely made She had an artless grace about her that endeared her to strangers. Root: art (from Latin ars, meaning “skill” or “craft”), Suffix: -less (meaning “without”)

Front: Define: ascetic (uh-set-ik)
Back: adj. relating to self-denial n. a person who practices self-denial The ascetic monks rejected modern comforts such as electricity. Root: ascet (from Greek asketes, meaning “monk” or “hermit”)

Front: Define: ascendant (uh-sen-dent)
Back: adj. rising adj. most powerful n. a position of being dominant or in control In this game, newcomers are ascendant because of their youth. Root: ascend (from Latin ascendere, meaning “to climb”), Suffix: -ant (used to form adjectives or nouns indicating an agent or something that performs the action)

Front: Define: ascribe (uh-scribe)
Back: v. to attribute or assign to a cause Her success was ascribed to the hours she had spent studying. Prefix: a- (from Latin, meaning “to”), Root: scribe (from Latin scribere, meaning “to write”)

Front: Define: assiduous (uh-sidj-oo-us)
Back: adj. making careful and persistent effort John was an assiduous student who always tried his best. Prefix: as- (variant of ad-, from Latin, meaning “to”), Root: sid (from Latin sedere, meaning “to sit”), Suffix: -uous (forming adjectives)

Front: Define: assuage (uh-swaydj)
Back: v. to relieve Her anger was assuaged by her friend's soothing words. Prefix: as- (variant of ad-, from Latin, meaning “to”), Root: suage (from Latin suavis, meaning “sweet”)

Front: Define: astute (uh-stewt)
Back: adj. having practical intelligence and good judgment An astute teacher always checks for plagiarism. Root: astut (from Latin astutus, meaning “shrewd” or “crafty”)

Front: Define: suppliant (suhp-lee-uhnt)
Back: adj. asking humbly, beseeching n. a person who requests or begs The boy was peering into the pet store window with the look of a suppliant on his face. Root: suppli (from Latin supplicare, meaning “to plead humbly”), Suffix: -ant (used to form adjectives or nouns indicating an agent or something that performs the action)

Front: Define: atrophy (at-ruh-fee)
Back: n. deterioration (esp. due to inactivity) v. to deteriorate, to waste away (esp. due to inactivity) The paralyzed patient began to show signs of atrophy in his leg muscles. Prefix: a- (from Greek, meaning “not” or “without”), Root: troph (from Greek trophe, meaning “nourishment”)

Front: Define: anosmia (an-oz-mee-uh)
Back: n. loss of the sense of smell Melissa has been afflicted with anosmia since birth; she likes to say that sometimes it is a curse, and sometimes a blessing. Prefix: an- (from Greek, meaning “without”), Root: osmia (from Greek osme, meaning “smell”)

Front: Define: austere (aw-steer)
Back: adj. severe, strict, or very plain The austere room was anything but inviting. Root: auster (from Greek austeros, meaning “harsh” or “severe”)

Front: Define: autonomous (aw-tawn-ih-muss)
Back: adj. independent The revolutionaries are fighting to make their country autonomous. Prefix: auto- (from Greek, meaning “self”), Root: nom (from Greek nomos, meaning “law”), Suffix: -ous (forming adjectives)

Front: Define: rapacious (ruh-pey-shuhs)
Back: adj. voracious, greedy, plundering The Vikings were rapacious warriors. Root: rapac (from Latin rapax, meaning “greedy”), Suffix: -ious (forming adjectives)

Front: Define: avarice (av-uh-riss)
Back: n. insatiable greed The rich man's avarice led him to buy up most of the neighborhood. Root: avar (from Latin avaritia, meaning “greed”)

Front: Define: unflappable (uhn-flap-uh-buhl)
Back: adj. not easily upset or excited (e.g., in a crisis) The unflappable hero maintained his level-headed mentality during the disaster. Prefix: un- (meaning “not”), Root: flap (from Middle English flappen, meaning “to flap”), Suffix: -able (forming adjectives)

Front: Define: aver (uh-vurr)
Back: v. to declare as true When interviewed, Susan's friends all averred that she was a trustworthy person. Prefix: a- (from Latin, meaning “to”), Root: ver (from Latin verus, meaning “true”)

Front: Define: emasculate (uh-mass-kyuh-leyt)
Back: v. to castrate or make effeminate v. to weaken Wearing the frilly pink shirt made him feel emasculated. Prefix: e- (from Latin, meaning “out”), Root: mascul (from Latin masculus, meaning “male”), Suffix: -ate (forming verbs)

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. in a state of decline adj. self-indulgent Hint: starts with “d”
Back: decadent synonyms: decaying, hedonistic, luxurious, indulgent The once-vibrant city now appeared decadent, with crumbling buildings and empty streets. The decadent lifestyle of the wealthy left them morally bankrupt.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her ________ behavior at the formal event impressed the guests. Hint: Starts with “d” and means “proper and tasteful”.
Back: decorous decorous (dek-core-us) adj. conforming to what is acceptable to society adj. marked by propriety and etiquette

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. to strongly disapprove of Hint: starts with “d”
Back: decry synonyms: denounce, deplore, condemn, criticize, vilify The politician decried the corruption in the system.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her ________ charm made her instantly likable. Hint: Starts with “a” and means “without deceit; natural”.
Back: artless artless (art-liss) adj. simple and natural adj. unable to mask true feelings adj. without artistic merit; crudely made

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. relating to self-denial; and n. a person who practices self-denial Hint: starts with “a”
Back: ascetic synonyms: abstinent, restrained, austere, self-disciplined, rigorous His ascetic lifestyle was characterized by minimal possessions and strict routines. The ascetic devoted his life to meditation and reflection, seeking enlightenment through simplicity.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ sun signaled the start of a new day. Hint: Starts with “a” and means “rising in power or influence”.
Back: ascendant ascendant (uh-sen-dent) adj. rising adj. most powerful n. a position of being dominant or in control

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to attribute or assign to a cause Hint: starts with “a”
Back: ascribe synonyms: assign, appoint, accredit, attribute, impute He ascribed his success to hard work and determination.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her ________ attention to detail ensured the project was flawless. Hint: Starts with “a” and means “showing great care and perseverance”.
Back: assiduous assiduous (uh-sidj-oo-us) adj. making careful and persistent effort

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to relieve Hint: starts with “a”
Back: assuage synonyms: soothe, alleviate, ease, calm, pacify He tried to assuage her guilt with comforting words.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her ________ observations helped the team solve the problem quickly. Hint: Starts with “a” and means “keenly perceptive or shrewd”.
Back: astute astute (uh-stewt) adj. having practical intelligence and good judgment

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. asking humbly, beseeching n. a person who requests or begs Hint: starts with “s”
Back: suppliant synonyms: begging; beggar, seeker, humble, beseeching, pleading, imploring The suppliant tone of her voice revealed her deep desire for help. As a suppliant, he approached the council for assistance in his plight.

Front: Fill in the blank: Muscle ________ can occur when a person is bedridden for an extended period. Hint: Starts with “a” and means “wasting away of body or abilities”.
Back: atrophy atrophy (at-ruh-fee) n. deterioration (esp. due to inactivity) v. to deteriorate, to waste away (esp. due to inactivity)

Front: Name the vocab term: n. loss of the sense of smell Hint: starts with “a”
Back: anosmia synonyms: without smell, smell loss, olfactory loss She was diagnosed with anosmia after a severe illness.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ decor of the room matched her minimalist lifestyle. Hint: Starts with “a” and means “severe or strict in manner”.
Back: austere austere (aw-steer) adj. severe, strict, or very plain

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. independent Hint: starts with “a”
Back: autonomous synonyms: self-determining, independent, self-governing, sovereign, free, self-sufficient The island nation remained autonomous despite political pressures.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ invaders took everything of value from the village. Hint: Starts with “r” and means “aggressively greedy”.
Back: rapacious rapacious (ruh-pey-shuhs) adj. voracious, greedy, plundering

Front: Name the vocab term: n. insatiable greed Hint: starts with “a”
Back: avarice synonyms: selfishness, ambition, greed, covetousness, insatiability, materialism His avarice led him to exploit his employees without remorse.

Front: Fill in the blank: Even in the face of disaster, he remained ________ and calm. Hint: Starts with “u” and means “calm under pressure”.
Back: unflappable unflappable (uhn-flap-uh-buhl) adj. not easily upset or excited (e.g., in a crisis)

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to declare as true Hint: starts with “a”
Back: aver synonyms: affirm, assert, declare, state She averred her innocence during the trial.

Front: Fill in the blank: The harsh criticism seemed to ________ his confidence in the project. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “weaken or deprive of strength”.
Back: emasculate emasculate (uh-mass-kyuh-leyt) v. to castrate or make effeminate v. to weaken

Front: Define: dormant (door-munt)
Back: adj. inactive for a period of time The dormant volcano erupted unexpectedly, injuring many. Root: dorm (from Latin dormire, meaning “to sleep”)

Front: Define: recumbent (rih-kuhm-buhnt)
Back: adj. leaning, lying down He sat recumbent on the picnic blanket. Prefix: re- (meaning “back” or “again”), Root: cumb (from Latin cumbere, meaning “to lie down”)

Front: Define: dote (dote)
Back: v. to show excessive affection Her parents were strict but her grandparents always doted on her and showered her with gifts. Root: dot (from Middle English doten, meaning “to be foolish”)

Front: Define: frangible (fran-djuh-buhl)
Back: adj. fragile; easily broken The frangible statue was accidently pushed over and shattered. Root: frang (from Latin frangere, meaning “to break”), Suffix: -ible (meaning “capable of”)

Front: Define: dupe (dewp)
Back: n. a person who is easily tricked v. to deceive The lying politician made those who had voted for him seem like dupes. Root: dup (from French dupe, meaning “deceived person”)

Front: Define: magnanimous (mag-nan-uh-muhss)
Back: adj. noble in spirit, generous in forgiving others Susan's magnanimous personality made her many life-long friends. Prefix: magn- (from Latin magnus, meaning “great”), Root: anim (from Latin animus, meaning “mind” or “spirit”), Suffix: -ous (meaning “full of”)

Front: Define: ebb (eb)
Back: v. to decrease or recede n. a decline n. the outward flow of the tide Her affection for him began to ebb a few days after the hasty wedding. Root: ebb (from Old English ebbian, meaning “to recede”)

Front: Define: wizen (wiz-uhn)
Back: adj. shriveled, wrinkled, or withered, as of with old age A wizened old man was walking through the park. Root: wiz (from Middle English wisen, meaning “to dry up”)

Front: Define: countermand (koun-ter-mand)
Back: v. to annul, cancel, make a contrary order The general countermanded his previous order to retreat, telling the men to march straight into battle. Prefix: counter- (meaning “against”), Root: mand (from Latin mandare, meaning “to order”)

Front: Define: ebullient (ih-buhl-yunt)
Back: adj. very excited; joyously enthusiastic Linda was ebullient when she made it into the semifinals. Prefix: e- (meaning “out”), Root: bull (from Latin bullire, meaning “to boil”), Suffix: -ient (indicating an adjective form)

Front: Define:: apogee (ap-uh-djee)
Back: n. the highest point, zenith The apogee of the roller coaster terrified even the most seasoned riders. Prefix: apo- (from Greek, meaning “away from”), Root: gee (from Greek gē, meaning “earth”)

Front: Define: ecclesiastical (ih-klee-zee-ass-tih-kuhl)
Back: adj. relating to the church Mary decided to take up her ecclesiastical concerns with the local priest. Root: ecclesi (from Greek ekklesia, meaning “assembly”), Suffix: -astical (relating to or characteristic of)

Front: Define: eclectic (ih-klek-tik)
Back: adj. composed of parts from many different sources The girl's fashion sense was an eclectic mix of conservative Victorian and colorful modern styles. Prefix: ec- (from Greek ek, meaning “out”), Root: lect (from Greek legein, meaning “to choose”)

Front: Define: edify (ed-ih-fahy)
Back: v. to educate, instruct, or benefit, especially morally or spiritually; uplift John attempted to edify the impolite young man. Root: ed (from Latin aedificare, meaning “to build”), Suffix: -ify (meaning “to make”)

Front: Define: efficacious (eff-ih-kay-shuss)
Back: adj. producing or able to produce a desired result The woman insisted that her herbal medicines would be the most efficacious remedy for the young patient. Root: effic (from Latin efficere, meaning “to accomplish”), Suffix: -acious (indicating having the quality of)

Front: Define: puerile (pyoo-er-ill)
Back: adj. childish, immature The comedian had a puerile sense of humor, invoking the bathroom in practically every joke. Root: puer (from Latin puer, meaning “boy”), Suffix: -ile (indicating relating to or capable of)

Front: Define: effrontery (ih-frun-tuh-ree)
Back: n. unjustified arrogance or boldness Although my sister had not invited me to her party, she had the effrontery to ask me for help setting up. Prefix: ef- (variant of ex-, meaning “out”), Root: front (from Latin frons, meaning “forehead” or “front”)

Front: Define: effusive (ih-few-siv)
Back: adj. related to excessive or unchecked emotion; expressing feelings of gratitude Susan's effusive praise of Ramon's new car made him think that perhaps she didn't really like it. Prefix: ef- (variant of ex-, meaning “out”), Root: fus (from Latin fundere, meaning “to pour”), Suffix: -ive (indicating having the nature of)

Front: Define: tortuous (tawr-choo-uhs)
Back: adj. winding, excessively complicated The philosopher made a tortuous argument that not many of his students followed. Root: tort (from Latin torquere, meaning “to twist”), Suffix: -uous (indicating full of or having the quality of)

Front: Define: debauchery (dih-baw-chuh-ree)
Back: n. extreme sensual indulgence The debauchery in the movie was enough to make me blush. Prefix: de- (indicating removal or reversal), Root: bauch (from Middle French baucher, meaning “to turn aside”), Suffix: -ery (indicating a practice or condition)

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. inactive for a period of time Hint: starts with “d”
Back: dormant synonyms: inactive, sleeping, inoperative, latent, idle, resting The volcano has been dormant for centuries.

Front: Fill in the blank: He remained ________ on the couch, watching TV. Hint: Starts with “r” and means “lying down”.
Back: recumbent recumbent (rih-kuhm-buhnt) adj. leaning, lying down

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to show excessive affection Hint: starts with “d”
Back: dote synonyms: favor, cherish, adore, pamper She couldn't help but dote on her new puppy.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ glass shattered upon impact. Hint: Starts with “f” and means “fragile or breakable”.
Back: frangible frangible (fran-djuh-buhl) adj. fragile; easily broken

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a person who is easily tricked v. to deceive Hint: starts with “d”
Back: dupe synonyms: chump, sucker, victim, fool, gull He was such a dupe, falling for every scam. The con artist duped him into giving away his money.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her ________ gesture of forgiveness surprised everyone. Hint: Starts with “m” and means “generous and forgiving”.
Back: magnanimous magnanimous (mag-nan-uh-muhss) adj. noble in spirit, generous in forgiving others

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to decrease or recede n. a decline n. the outward flow of the tide Hint: starts with “e”
Back: ebb synonyms: subside; regression, decline, diminution, retreat As the excitement began to ebb, the crowd slowly dispersed. The ebb of support left the candidate discouraged.

Front: Fill in the blank: The once vibrant flowers began to ________ in the heat. Hint: Starts with “w” and means “to shrivel or dry up”.
Back: wizen wizen (wiz-uhn) v. to shrivel, wrinkle, or wither, as of old age

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to annul or cancel; to give a contrary order Hint: starts with “c”
Back: countermand synonyms: override, recall, revoke, rescind, retract The general countermanded the earlier attack order.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ crowd cheered loudly for their team. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “cheerful and full of energy”.
Back: ebullient ebullient (ih-buhl-yunt) adj. very excited; joyously enthusiastic

Front: Name the vocab term: n. the highest point, zenith Hint: starts with “a”
Back: apogee synonyms: pinnacle, apex, summit, peak The astronaut reached the apogee of his career with the moon landing.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ leaders gathered for the annual conference. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “relating to the church”.
Back: ecclesiastical ecclesiastical (ih-klee-zee-ass-tih-kuhl) adj. relating to the church

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. composed of parts from many different sources Hint: starts with “e”
Back: eclectic synonyms: heterogeneous, multifarious, varied, diverse Her music taste is quite eclectic, ranging from classical to punk rock.

Front: Fill in the blank: The speaker's words were meant to ________ the audience. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “to instruct morally or intellectually”.
Back: edify edify (ed-ih-fahy) v. to educate, instruct, or benefit, especially morally or spiritually; uplift

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. producing or able to produce a desired result Hint: starts with “e”
Back: efficacious synonyms: efficient, capable, effective, potent The treatment was efficacious in curing the disease.

Front: Fill in the blank: His ________ jokes irritated everyone at the meeting. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “childishly silly”.
Back: puerile puerile (pyoo-er-ill) adj. childish, immature

Front: Name the vocab term: n. unjustified arrogance or boldness Hint: starts with “e”
Back: effrontery synonyms: audacity, impudence, brashness, insolence He had the effrontery to insult the host at the dinner party.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her ________ praise made everyone in the room uncomfortable. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “expressing feelings freely or unrestrainedly”.
Back: effusive effusive (ih-few-siv) adj. related to excessive or unchecked emotion; expressing feelings of gratitude

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. winding, excessively complicated Hint: starts with “t”
Back: tortuous synonyms: ambiguous, convoluted, indirect, circuitous, twisted The legal contract was so tortuous that no one could understand it.

Front: Fill in the blank: The party was known for its ________ and excess. Hint: Starts with “d” and means “excessive indulgence in pleasures”.
Back: debauchery debauchery (dih-baw-chuh-ree) n. extreme sensual indulgence
